info.headline: Flood Advisory issued February 03 at 9:27PM EST until February 06 at 1:52PM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 AM EST FRIDAY... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...A portion of northeast Georgia, including the following counties, Habersham and Rabun. * WHEN...Until 900 AM EST Friday. * IMPACTS...Nuisance to Minor flooding of common, flood-prone areas is likely. Expect impacts to low-water crossings, boat-access areas, low-elevation roadways adjacent to streams, poorly draining urban areas and intersections, campgrounds, greenways, and parks. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 906 PM EST, Over the past 24 hours, Rabun and Habersham counties have received anywhere from 2 to 5 inches of rainfall due to numerous rounds of light to moderate showers. Fortunately, the area was unusually dry in advance of the rainfall and area streams and drainages have been able to accommodate the runoff. However, additional rounds of moderate to, at times, heavy rainfall, with rain rates of 1-2 inches per hour, are beginning to move over the area, with additional heavy showers moving towards the area from southwest to northeast. Additional rainfall of 1-3" is possible through the early overnight hours and this will cause several streams to approach and exceed bankfull, causing nuisance to Minor flooding of flood-prone, low-lying areas. - The Tallulah River above Lake Burton will likely exceed bankfull, causing nuisance flooding of adjacent low-lying areas including around Fred Thompson Road. Expect the Tallulah River to exceed 5 feet by 1am and crest between 5 and 6 feet overnight. The Soque River near Clarkesville is near bankfull and is beginning to flood adjacent low-lying areas, including around Pitts Park and Beaver Dam Rd. Expect the river to crest near 11.1 feet by 10pm but then resume additional rises and make another crest between 12 and 13 feet later tonight. Tiger Creek at W Wolf Creek Rd in Lakemont is currently at 2 feet but is rising again in response to the new rounds of rainfall. Expect some nuisance flooding along Tiger Creek overnight as the stream crests between 3 and 5 feet. Additional rises are possible so please stay away from all streams and stay weather-aware. - Some locations that will experience nuisance to Minor flooding include... Toccoa, Clayton, Clarkesville, Cornelia, Baldwin, Demorest, Mount Airy, Alto, Mountain City, Tiger, Dillard, Sky Valley, Tallulah Falls, Lake Rabun, Lakemont, Lake Burton, Black Rock Mountain State Park, Raoul and Seed Lake.
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. In hilly terrain there are hundreds of low water crossings which are potentially dangerous in heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded roads. Find an alternate route.
